Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: The Ecological Basis of Hunting and Meat Sharing in Female Savanna Chimpanzees

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
Hunting with tools may enable female chimpanzees to routinely ingest and share meat on a seasonal basis without the need for being provisioned by males. This project will capture the dietary impacts of female chimpanzee hunting with tools and compare these findings with other studies that have focused primarily on male chimpanzee hunting behaviors. The findings from this project will advance knowledge and broaden perspectives about primate models for understanding human behavioral evolution. This project increases capacity for chimpanzee research by fully engaging with and supporting local partners and students. The research is part of a long-term program that supports habitat preservation in protected and unprotected areas for the critically-endangered western chimpanzee. The research further engages in conservation activities through the active study of conservation genetics, development of conservation action plans, and support of local research and community services in the research area. The project provides exceptional research opportunities for undergraduate and graduate students, especially underrepresented minority and first-generation students to support diversity and inclusion efforts in biological anthropology and STEM, more broadly. This project also interfaces with Purdue Universityâ€™s EPICS program (Engineering Projects in Community Service) to provide collaborative design experiences for undergraduate students.

Sexual selection theory and patterns of male-biased hunting and meat eating for chimpanzees (Pan troglodytes) have been traditionally integrated with models of human behavioral evolution. While there is a well-documented understanding of these behaviors in forest chimpanzees, a significant gap exists on how chimpanzees hunt and eat meat in savannas. What little is known about hunting and meat-eating in savanna chimpanzees, however, starkly contrasts with the typical species pattern. In the hottest, driest, and most open landscapes inhabited by chimpanzees, tool use and female-biased hunting comprise a major component of hunting strategy. This study will test for environmental pressures that may explain this behavior. Little is known about female-biased hunting because these timid chimpanzees are not habituated for intensive behavior sampling, and are not being habituated due to their conservation status combined with risk of infant poaching for the pet trade. To confront this challenge, the project combines behavioral, isotopic, nutritional, genetic, visual analytic, and geographic approaches to compare hunting and meat ingestion between females and males, and in relation to climate and food availability. This interdisciplinary and multi-site study is a part of the HUNTRESS project on HUnting, Nutrition, Tool-use, Reproductive Ecology, and meat Sharing in Savanna chimpanzees to holistically assess female-biased hunting. The project will measure meat ingestion with stable isotope and feeding trace analyses, and compare these signatures to direct observations of hunting and meat ingestion in a reference group of habituated adult males. Furthermore, the project will compare meat ingestion to annual climate trends as well as food and macronutrient availability. A molecular component will enable sex-determination and individualization information from hair and feces. The video analytics component will measure mammal (prey) availability remotely from camera-trap videos and still images. At the same, the research will advance machine-learning capabilities by incorporating domain knowledge to improve accuracy and precision of mammal localization.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project evaluates the hypothesis that hunting with tools enables female chimpanzees in Senegal to ingest meat at similar rates to males. The key finding of this study is that females and males are ingesting animal tissues at equivalent levels, as determined from carbon (δ13C) and nitrogen (δ15N) isotopes measured from non-invasively collected hair and fecal samples. This result contrasts with a widespread pattern of male-biased hunting and meat ingesting in wild chimpanzees, challenging the idea that females primarily acquire meat through male provisioning. Study findings support the hypothesis that hunting with tools improves females’ access to meat in some chimpanzee populations. Additional findings include: (1) differences in δ15N values among chimpanzee groups, indicating that prey availability and animal tissue ingestion were lower for chimpanzees in unprotected areas in Senegal, and (2) hunting rates and hair δ15N values from chimpanzees in unprotected areas decreased over the last decade.

We used camera traps to systematically sample mammals for prey abundance estimation. Camera traps generate large quantities of data and require a substantial amount of labor from human annotators to review and label images. To minimize this annotation effort, we used computer vision methods and tools for automating animal detection and classification. However, our camera trap imagery from Senegal exhibited an out-of-domain challenge for existing animal detector and classifier tools. We found these tools to be brittle due to multiple mismatches between prior training datasets and the qualities of our wildlife data, such as the specific mammal species, complex natural environments, lighting conditions, and objects appearing at low resolution. In our case, effective use of animal detection and classifier tools required the development of a customized pipeline. Customization involved extensive human annotation, training, methods development, and performance testing.

Broader Impacts: Research products include five peer-reviewed publications, 18 conference presentations, and two theses. This project provided funded research opportunities for five graduate students (three minority, two women) and research internships for 29 undergraduate (UG) students (14 minority, 20 women). Fifty-five percent (55%) of these undergraduates are working on their degrees, 28% are in advanced or professional degree programs, 10% joined the workforce after graduation, and 7% completed an advanced degree and entered the work force. This award supported research facilities infrastructure improvements in the U.S. and Senegal, and capacity building for local primatologists in a great ape range country. In Senegal, this project supported local scientists and graduate students, provided living wages for local staff, ensured shared access to databases by using online repositories and network storage tools, and offered professional development training opportunities. Results of our habitat monitoring work on the critically-endangered western chimpanzee were shared with wildlife conservation and management experts in Senegal.
